Award.AwardTitle: A design for a study that will determine whether an outreach project that has been supported by NSF TCUP has impacted math learning among Native Americans

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Tribal Nations Research Group (TNRG), a federally recognized and Tribal 501c3 non-profit organization, is proposing an 18-month planning project that will gather the necessary information to design a study to determine the effectiveness and the impact of a Tribal Colleges and Universities Program (TCUP) funded outreach project, the Sunday Academy Model (SAM). Sunday Academy is a collaborative and culturally sensitive STEM learning outreach model that from 2001 to 2015 was partially supported with funding from TCUP. The North Dakota Tribal Colleges in partnership with North Dakota State University (NDSU) administered the project. Additionally, the proposed project will explore ways to explain the role the NSF Tribal College Rural Systemic Initiative (1994-2005) had in establishing the necessary and preliminary environmental and academic atmosphere for the Sunday Academy project at the participating tribal colleges and the American Indian communities being served.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Description

The project team completed a study design to determine whether the Sunday Academy Model (SAM) impacted STEM learning among Native Americans.  Over the last 25 years, the NSF has made a substantial investment in programs that are intended to improve Native American participation and success in STEM. The five North Dakota tribal colleges, representing Ojibway, Lakota, Nakota, Dakota, Mandan, Arikara, and Hidatsa Tribal Nations implemented the SAM in monthly Sunday Academy (SA) curricula. Approximately 2000 students have participated in the SAM project over the last 25 years. SAM is a culturally guided STEM outreach collaborative that has existed since the late 1990s.

The process of obtaining the data necessary to verify this correlational relationship includes:

  • Through focus groups, the leadership committee will establish ?success? criterion.
  • Verifying through a survey of SA faculty that the specific instructional approaches during SA lessons are similar to Vygotsky?s instructional theory and best practice in teaching Native American students.
  • Names and contact information of past Sunday Academy (SA) participants will be acquired through collaborating TCUs.
  • Acquired names will be matched with names of Tribal Scholarship Program applicants.
  • A matched sample of students who did not attend SA will also be selected as the control group.
  • Contact information for each SA student and control group selected will be documented.
  • Local Discovery Teams in each TCU community will seek out family and others to acquire current SA participant and control group contact information.
  • SA participants will be requested to sign a consent form to complete the Research Participant Profile and Survey Form (RPPSF) that will provide specific demographic data and perceptions of SA experiences, subsequent high school and college experiences that can be documented for analysis.
  • Tribal Scholarship Program records will be accessed. Data available in these records include high school transcripts and each semester transcript from the college/university attended.
  • The secondary/quantitative data will be coded and analyzed and primary/qualitative data will be transcribed, coded, and analyzed.

 Intellectual Merit

The investigators found that the Sunday Academy Model (SAM) is a unique culturally driven outreach approach to teaching Native American middle and high school students to encourage them in a learning milieu and teaching practice that is transformative. Understanding more about the impact of this approach can lead to the implementation of this model to other fields such as social sciences, and language.  Once studied and tested, this model may also be adaptable to other diverse populations.  Other minority-serving institutions may want to use this model to increase learning for the student population they serve.

Broader Impact

This longitudinal study as created through this project will investigate over 25 years of SAM implementation.  The overall focus of the project is to study the impact of outreach strategies and foundational importance of the cross-cultural and cross-institutional partnerships that provide the ?cultural link? that can change American Indian students? perceptions of and success in the STEM fields. Not only will this study provide documentation of The SAM on individual students, but also how other TCUs might replicate this model into STEM efforts and other disciplines. In addition, institutions of higher learning will have a model that has impacted an increase in student diversity within the STEM departments.
